captions.text: OK, so today we've got a little
mathematical nugget for you.

I'm going to talk about
10 factorial.

So 10 factorial is what you
get when you multiply the

numbers 10 times 9
times 8 times 7--

and you go all the way down,
times 2, times 1.
How big is 10 factorial?

On your calculator you will find
a little bottom with an
exclamation mark after it.
There we go.

That is how big 10
factorial is.
Let's write this down.

Now what I want to talk about
is 10 factorial seconds.

Now, how long is 10
factorial seconds?

All right, so 3,628,800
seconds.
How long is that?

Well, it turns out to be
exactly six weeks.
Let me show you.

We've got 10 factorial
seconds, so how
many minutes is that?

There are 60 seconds in
a minute, so I'm going
to divide by 60.
60 is 10 times 3 times 2.

That's the way I'm
going to do it.
So I'm going to divide by 60.

I can just cancel out
10 and 3 and 2.
That's a way to divide by 60.

I might as well cancel out the
1 as well, while I'm at it.
How many hours is that?

I'm going to divide
by 60 again.

Another way to write 60
is 5 times 4 times 3.
That also equals 60.

I'm going to cancel out
the 5 and the 4.
And I want to cancel 3.
I don't have it.

I'm going to take the
9, divide by 3.

So that now becomes
a 3 instead.

This is how many minutes
we've got.
How many hours is that?
I want to divide by 24.
24 is 8 times 3.

Divide by 8, and that
now disappears.
Fantastic.
24 is gone.

So this is how many
hours it is.
How many weeks is that?

There are seven days
in a week.
I want to divide by 7.
That's how many weeks it is.
How many weeks is it?
What's left?
Six.

There are exactly six weeks
for 10 factorial seconds.
Exactly.

So if you're at school, and if
you're looking forward to your

six weeks holiday, and oh, it
doesn't seem like long enough,

well, perhaps you might like
to think of it as your 10
factorial second holiday.

So let's try this from
the other direction.

So how many seconds are
there in six weeks?
So we've got six weeks.
How many days is that?

How many days are there
in six weeks?
We're going to times by 7.
Seven days a week.
How many hours is that?
24 hours in a day.
So we're going to times by 24.
How many minutes is that?
Well, let's times by 60.

60 minutes in an hour, and then
times by 60 again because

there's 60 seconds
in a minute.

This is how many seconds
you get in six weeks.
Now we get our calculator.

Let's see if we do get what
I said it was going to be.

6 weeks times 7 days times 24
hours times 60 minutes times

60 seconds is exactly
what I said before.

3,628,800, or to put it another
way, 10 factorial.

comments.text:
Factorials aren't linear in any way; with the exeption of 0, 1, and 2, they 
get big a lot faster than quadratics, so you shouldn't expect *(2x)!* to be 
equal to double *x!* unless x is 1.

For example, say x is 4.

*4! = 24*, and *24 X 2 = 48*

*8! = 40,320* which is obviously larger than 48.

comments.author: John Sherlock

comments.text:
This is interesting but not really purely coincidental. It was decided that 
there would be 60 seconds in a minute and 60 minutes in an hour because 60 
is has many factors. Meaning, a half hour is 30 minutes, a third of an hour 
is 20 minutes, a quarter of an hour is 15 minutes, a fifth of an hour is 12 
minutes, a sixth of an hour is 10 minutes. So its not that surprising that 
alot of the factors in the 10! "cross out" during this calculation. Its 
more of a slight coincidence than a huge elegant coincidence, since the 
number 60 was decided specifically because it has alot of factors.﻿

comments.author: IVAN3DX

comments.text:
+IVAN3DX Halves, thirds, fourths, fifths plus the tenths and other 
multiples are all there in base 60.  You're losing 3 as a factor by 
changing it to base 10 and gaining nothing except familiarity with base 10, 
which is a major loss since 3 is a low prime factor and the key argument 
for why people think things should have been in sexagesimal or duodecimal 
in the first place (and they were, hence 60 minutes/360 degrees).  The one 
nice thing about base 10, I guess, is that you have the same number of 
fingers... /blows party popper
comments.author: gumenski

comments.text:
+gumenski But you can easily say "A third of an hour" or just say the

comments.author: GraveNoX

comments.text:
No, we have leap days every 4 years to keep the seasons lined up, not 
because the day is an extra 6 seconds longer. The mean solar day is 24 
hours and about 2 microseconds long. Those 2 microseconds come from the 
fact that the Earth's rotation has slowed very slightly since the length of 
the second was standardized several decades ago. The length of any 
particular solar day actually varies over the course of the year due to 
Earth's elliptical orbit around the Sun, and it's axial tilt. The 
accumulation of these variations is measured by the Equation of Time.

Factorials grow crazy fast. If 10! = # of seconds in 6 weeks, then 11!

comments.text:
Pretty late reply, but the digits of any multiple of 9 add up to 9.
6! is 6x5x4x3x2x1, notice how the 6 can be split into 3x2, and you now you 
have two threes in there, which makes 9. Any factorial after 6! contains 
6!, so they all add up to 9.
